Award.AwardTitle: Engineering Silver Clusters for Molecular Measurement
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Yeh at University of Texas at Austin and Professor Petty at Furman University are studying the properties of small metallic particles, termed silver clusters. Due to the special chemical, physical and optical properties of silver clusters, these tiny particles have been made into a variety of colorful molecular sensors for detection of disease-related DNA and modifications on DNA. But we do not understand what really controls the color, the stability, and synthesis yield of these wonderful nanomaterials. The project seeks to answer these fundamental questions, with the end goal to engineer and harness silver clusters for a diversity of biological sensing and imaging applications. Undergraduate and high school students at Furman characterize the chromophores and the graduate students at UT-Austin at the same time develop their sensing applications. The collaboration and feedback between the two groups are the linchpin that drives the development of new nanosensors. Furthermore, the PIs outreach to local high schools to integrate a larger group of interested and talented students. These research activities will inspire a diverse group of curious students to share in the excitement of scientific innovation.

Future progress in fluorescence detection and imaging is hampered by the scarcity of functional probes. Professors Yeh and Petty are developing a novel class of switchable and tunable silver clusters that are conjugated with DNA strands. They are addressing core factors that control the chemical stabilities, biocompatibilities, and optical properties of silver clusters using a wealth of purification and analysis techniques such as HPLC, SEC, CD, MS, ICP-AES and DNA footprinting. Silver clusters present new opportunities for molecular sensing and imaging because of their strong, activatable emission. The transformative integration of physical/analytical chemistry, molecular engineering, and photonics will create a versatile set of toolkit for diverse applications, including personalized medicine, super-resolution microscopy, and biothreat detection.

POR.DRECONTENT:
DNA-bound silver clusters are chromophores with strong fluorescence, and we now more thoroughly understand the photophysics of these complexes. Femtosecond transient spectroscopy probed the excited electronic states of the clusters and show that specific DNA contacts can control the cluster brightness. We have developed a new instrument to measure the slow phosphorescence from triplet states in these clusters. These lifetimes depend on the structure of the DNA host, and we studied bifurcated and contiguous DNA hosts. Crystallography was used to understand how the silvers arrange within a DNA host, and these studies identified distinct types of silvers within the complex.

In addition, we have determined the binding sites of Ag10 silver clusters in two different DNA hosts using UV-activated electron photodetachment mass spectrometry. This hybrid mass spectrometry approach allowed us to gain structural insight into these nanoscale chromophores. Both DNA strands template Ag10 clusters, but create distinct fluorophores due to their different footprints of silver clusters within their polymeric DNA hosts. Moreover, we have purified the DNA-silver cluster complexes using size-exclusion chromatography and improved the performance of the silver cluster sensors by blocking the unlabeled probes.

This project has provided a distinctive opportunity to combine not only technical expertise of the PIs but also the educational opportunities at their two institutions. The graduate and undergraduate students at UT Austin (Yeh) have developed interdisciplinary knowledge and skills in chemical measurement, nanomaterial synthesis, biochemistry, materials science, analytical chemistry, biosensing, and advanced spectroscopy. The undergraduates at Furman (Petty) have not only acquired the new skill set needed for their independent research but also developed the ability to communicate their results. In Dr. Petty’s group, 8 students have made 7 presentations at ACS meetings and have been co-authors on 5 papers in ACS Nano and Analytical Chemistry in the past 5 years. UT Austin offers a strong, supportive environment for undergraduates, as shown by its continuing long-term support of the Undergraduate Student Fellowship. Dr. Yeh currently hosts 4 undergraduate students through this program. Two students’ projects are right along the silver cluster research. Four undergraduate students became co-authors on 4 silver cluster-related papers in Biosensors, ACS Nano, Nanoscale, Chem Comm, ACS Sensors and JACS in the past 5 years.

This grant also provided the opportunity to reach beyond the confines of our institutions into the broader community. Furman University has a long-term relationship with local high schools, and Dr. Petty has hosted two students in recent summers. These students are highly motivated and have been excellent research scientists. Both are co-authors on two papers in Analytical Chemistry. Both are pursing STEM degrees at their universities. Both PIs outreached to local high schools to integrate a larger group of interested and talented students. These research activities have inspired a diverse group of curious students to share in the excitement of scientific innovation.

The grant has also impacted the research of other faculty members in our departments. Furman has five professors involved in DNA-related research, with whom Dr. Petty collaborate extensively. Professor Laura Wright and Dr. Petty study DNA-ligand complexes using atomic force microscopy, and together we have mentored 4 students. Professor John Wheeler is an invaluable resource in the areas of chromatography and mass spectrometry. At UT Austin, Dr. Yeh is collaborating with Dr. Andrew Dunn in building new microscopes, where the developed photoactivatable silver cluster probes will be used for molecular imaging in the future, and with Dr. Jennifer Brodbelt in using UV photodissociation method in studying the Ag binding sites on DNA, which will facilitate the design of new sensors for chemical measurements.

To engage female and minority students and attract them to STEM majors, Dr. Yeh’s team has participated in the outreach activities of Women in Engineering Program (WEP) on the UT campus. Dr. Yeh often presented his silver cluster research on the UT Introduce a Girl to Engineering Day. Moreover, WEP’s national-award-winning Graduates Linked with Undergraduates in Engineering (GLUE) program has successfully given non-engineering female undergraduate students the opportunity to gain introductory, practical research experience by pairing them with the graduate students in Dr. Yeh’s lab. By participating in local high schools’ STEM Festivals through poster presentations and live demonstrations, we have brought many underrepresented students to the STEM field at UT.
